q: After that article appeared, tech blogger John Gruber gave Eric Schmidt a new title: attendees at a forum organized by the Atlantic Monthly heard him testify to how much Google could learn about its users with their permission: We don't need you to type at all. We know where you are. We know where you've been. We can more or less know what you're thinking about. * In an CNN interview later that month, Eric Schmidt joked that users offended by photos of their homes showing up in Google's Street View mapping feature could "just move." takes a longer-term look, based on EDD projections, to 2018. Network systems and data analysts, and medical scientists are the fastest growing occupations, but, despite the focus on "knowledge" jobs, the great majority of job openings will be in the low tech, non-professional positions, in jobs such as personal and home care aides, retail salespersons, cashiers, waiters and waitresses, and food preparation workers, Bernick concludes.
